title: Banks told to work harder for customers
text:
Competition watchdog tells banks to work harder for customers Emma Dunkley ©Bloomberg 
Banks in the UK will be forced to guide customers to rival current accounts in an attempt to stoke competition, but will not have to abandon free banking for people in credit or face being broken up. 
The competition watchdog said on Thursday that the largest lenders — Lloyds Banking Group , Barclays , Royal Bank of Scotland and HSBC — must alert customers to switch to another current account provider in situations such as a branch closure or technology glitch. More Inmarsat in deal for new Silk Road 
The proposed measure is part of the Competition Market Authority’s long-awaited investigation into the £16bn current account and business banking sector, following concerns that individuals and businesses were getting a raw deal in a market dominated by the big four banks. 
Current account holders could save £70 a year on average by switching banks, while those who are heavy overdraft users could save as much as £260 a year, the watchdog said. 
However, the review has stopped short of calling for an end to “free” current accounts, claiming there is “no convincing evidence” that it “distorted competition”. 
The watchdog is also not demanding a break-up of the large banks , taking the view that this would not fuel competition. TSB has already been carved out of Lloyds Banking Group, while Williams & Glyns is in the process of being spun out of Royal Bank of Scotland. 
A number of industry experts said the watchdog had not gone far enough. 
Jayne-Anne Gadhia, chief executive at Virgin Money , a challenger bank, said: “It is a small step forward but not transformational. I’m pleased that there is some progress but disappointed that it is so limited.” 
The British Chambers of Commerce said the CMA’s proposals were “unlikely to be game-changing”, adding that many businesses “will be disappointed with the results”. 
Richard Lloyd, executive director of consumer group Which?, said: “The CMA inquiry has to bring about better banking, but these proposals don’t go far enough. 
“The CMA’s own evidence is that consumers are disengaged from the banking market, so better information and nudges to switch will not be enough.” 
Nonetheless, Alasdair Smith, chairman of retail banking investigation at the CMA, warned that the proposed measures would have a “far-reaching impact” on how banks operate.
